content.text: The student makes two measurements to determine the average speed of the trolley as it travels down the slope
State the two measurements
For each measurement, suggest the instrument used for making the measurement
Determine the speed of the trolley at time \(= 2.0 \text{s}\)
Determine the distance moved by the trolley from time \(= 0\) to time \(= 4.0 \text{s}\)
distance =   .........  \(cm\)
Using the information in Fig. 1.1, describe the motion of the trolley from time \(= 0\) to time \(= 10 \text{s}\)
Fig. 1.1 shows the speedâ€“time graph for a different trolley as it travels down a slope
A student investigates the motion of a trolley as it travels down a slope
There are 270 sheets of paper in the textbook. The total thickness of the sheets is \(29 \text{mm}\)
Calculate the average thickness of **one** sheet of paper
average thickness of one sheet =   .........  mm
The mass of the textbook is 1300 g
Calculate the weight of the textbook
weight =   .........  N
Fig. 2.1 shows a closed textbook
Calculate the resultant horizontal force on the aeroplane
resultant force =   .........  N
direction of resultant force
State the name of the effect producing the \(8000\mathrm{N}\) force on the aeroplane
At a later time in the flight, the resultant horizontal force on the aeroplane is zero
Describe the horizontal motion of the aeroplane
Fig. 3.1 shows an aeroplane flying. There are horizontal forces acting on the aeroplane, as shown in Fig. 3.1
Fig. 3.2 shows the handle used to open and close a cupboard door on the aeroplane
A force of \(60 \text{N}\) acts at a distance of \(20 \text{cm}\) from the pivot of the handle
Calculate the moment of the \(60 \text{N}\) force about the pivot
moment =   .........  N cm
State the names of the parts of the power station labelled X and Y
X
Y
Describe two useful energy transfers in this power station
The power station contains a transformer. The primary voltage \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\) for the transformer is 25 000 V. The number of turns on the primary coil \(N_{\mathrm{p}}\) is 600
The number of turns on the secondary coil \(N_{\mathrm{s}}\) is 4800
Calculate the secondary voltage \(V_{\mathrm{s}}\) for the transformer
Give two reasons for transmitting electrical energy at very high voltages
Fig. 4.1 shows parts of a coal-fired power station
Explain how the shiny surfaces reduce the transfer of thermal energy from the hot liquid
Explain how the vacuum reduces the transfer of thermal energy from the hot liquid
Some of the hot liquid is poured out of the flask into a shallow dish
Explain how evaporation causes the liquid to cool
State the name given to the motion of the small particle
Explain why the small particle moves as shown in Fig. 5.2
A student uses a microscope to view a small particle in the liquid. Fig. 5.2 shows the path of the particle
Fig. 5.1 shows a cross-section of a flask. The flask is used to keep a liquid hot. The flask has two glass walls with a vacuum between them. The surfaces of the glass walls are shiny
Fig. 5.1
Complete the labelling in Fig. 6.1. Write the name of the radiation in each unlabelled region
State the name of one region of the electromagnetic spectrum that has wavelengths shorter than those of ultraviolet rays
Fig. 6.1 shows the main regions of the electromagnetic spectrum. Two of the regions are unlabelled
Fig. 6.2 represents a wave on a rope at one instant
On Fig. 6.2, draw a line representing **one** wavelength. Label the line L
A student incorrectly writes some sentences about electromagnetic waves. His teacher circles a mistake in each sentence
In Table 6.1, write a suitable correction for each mistake. The first one has been done for you

table.html:
student's sentencescorrection
The speed of light is slower than the speed of radio waves in a vacuum.the same as
Ultraviolet rays are used in signals for satellite television and mobile phones.
Radio waves are used to scan patients for broken bones.

content.text: Describe the difference between the vibrations of longitudinal waves and transverse waves
Using the information in Fig. 7.1, state the angle of refraction for the ray of red light travelling from air into the glass block
angle of refraction =   .........  Â°
Using the information in Fig. 7.1, state the term used for line X
A student investigates refraction through a parallel-sided glass block. Fig. 7.1 shows a ray of red light travelling from the air through the glass block
Two rays from the top of the object are incident on the lens, as shown in Fig. 7.2
On Fig. 7.2, continue the paths of these two rays to show the position of the image of OX formed by the lens
Draw the image of OX formed by the lens
Fig. 7.2 shows an object OX to the left of a thin converging lens. The principal focus on each side of the lens is labelled F
State which objects are made of electrically insulating materials
State which object is made of a magnetic material
A student has a box containing objects made of different materials. The objects are:
aluminium foil a silver ring an iron bar
a plastic strip a glass lens
Fig. 8.1 shows two magnets, X and Y. The magnets are attracting each other
On magnet X, the N pole is labelled N
On Fig. 8.1, complete the labelling for the magnetic poles of each magnet
The student puts a positive charge on sphere P only
Complete the diagram in Fig. 8.3 to show the positions of the spheres
The student puts a positive charge on sphere P and on sphere Q
Complete the diagram in Fig. 8.4 to show the positions of the spheres
The student attaches a thin cotton thread to each of two light metal spheres, P and Q. She suspends the spheres as shown in Fig. 8.2
Using standard symbols, draw a circuit diagram for the circuit in the torch
State the current in the brass connecting strip
current =   .........  A
Calculate the resistance of the lamp
resistance =   .........  \(\Omega\)
When the torch is switched on, the potential difference (p.d.) across the lamp is \(1.4 \text{V}\) and the current in the lamp is \(0.26 \text{A}\)
A student has a battery-operated torch. Fig. 9.1 shows the electrical components in the torch circuit
Fig. 10.1 shows a wire passing through a card. There is a large electric current in the wire in the direction shown
Fig. 10.2 shows the same arrangement when viewed from above the card
There is a pattern of magnetic field lines around the wire due to the current in the wire
On Fig. 10.2, draw the pattern and direction of the magnetic field as if viewed from above the card
State two different ways of increasing the force due to the current in the wire XY
State two different ways of making the force on the wire XY act downwards
Fig. 10.3 shows a wire XY carrying a large electric current between the poles of a permanent magnet. There is an upward force on the wire XY
An isotope of americium has 95 protons and 146 neutrons in its nucleus
Write the nuclide notation for the nucleus of this isotope. The chemical symbol for americium is Am
Fig. 11.1 shows how the count rate of a sample of americium changes with time
Determine the half-life of the americium in the sample. Use information from Fig. 11.1
half-life =   .........  years
